ParameterXml: <Param>Print spooler service is enabled on a DC</Param><Param>Critical</Param><Param>10</Param><Param>Mitre:Execution, Mitre:Lateral Movement, Mitre:Privilege Escalation</Param><Param>This indicator looks for Domain Controllers that have the print spooler service running. This service is enabled by default.</Param><Param>During June-July 2021, several critical flaws were found in Windows Print Spooler services- <a href="https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2021-1675" target="_blank">CVE-2021-1675</a> and <a href="https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2021-34527" target="_blank">CVE-2021-34527</a> which directly affect Print Spoolers installed on domain controllers, enabling remote code execution. See this <a href="https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-34527" target="_blank">link</a> for  Microsoft updates and patch information on this flaw.<br> In addition to this vulnerability, an existing weakness in print spoolers enabled on a DC, combined with unconstrained delegation object (see indicator 16 "Computer or user accounts with unconstrained delegation") may allow attackers to authenticate as that DC to any service (see this <a href="https://adsecurity.org/?p=4056" target="_blank">writeup</a> for additional information).</Param><Param>Run every hour starting on 7/4/2021 12:45:35 PM</Param>
EventData: <DataItem type="System.XmlData" time="2021-07-08T16:00:35.6862823+00:00" sourceHealthServiceId="3D6D4536-CDC3-6B7A-4D6B-703DA70423F0"><EventData xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/win/2004/08/events/event"><Data Name="securityIndicatorName">Print spooler service is enabled on a DC</Data><Data Name="severity">Critical</Data><Data Name="weight">10</Data><Data Name="securityFrameworkTags">Mitre:Execution, Mitre:Lateral Movement, Mitre:Privilege Escalation</Data><Data Name="securityIndicatorDescription">This indicator looks for Domain Controllers that have the print spooler service running. This service is enabled by default.</Data><Data Name="likelihoodOfCompromise">During June-July 2021, several critical flaws were found in Windows Print Spooler services- <a href="https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2021-1675" target="_blank">CVE-2021-1675</a> and <a href="https://cve.mitre.org/cgi-bin/cvename.cgi?name=CVE-2021-34527" target="_blank">CVE-2021-34527</a> which directly affect Print Spoolers installed on domain controllers, enabling remote code execution. See this <a href="https://msrc.microsoft.com/update-guide/vulnerability/CVE-2021-34527" target="_blank">link</a> for  Microsoft updates and patch information on this flaw.<br> In addition to this vulnerability, an existing weakness in print spoolers enabled on a DC, combined with unconstrained delegation object (see indicator 16 "Computer or user accounts with unconstrained delegation") may allow attackers to authenticate as that DC to any service (see this <a href="https://adsecurity.org/?p=4056" target="_blank">writeup</a> for additional information).</Data><Data Name="schedule">Run every hour starting on 7/4/2021 12:45:35 PM</Data></EventData></DataItem>
RenderedDescription:
New security indicator: Print spooler service is enabled on a DC Severity: Critical Weight: 10 Schedule: Run every hour starting on 7/4/2021 12:45:35 PM Security framework tags: Mitre:Execution, Mitre:Lateral Movement, Mitre:Privilege Escalation Security indicator description: This indicator looks for Domain Controllers that have the print spooler service running. This service is enabled by default. Likelihood of compromise: During June-July 2021, several critical flaws were found in Windows Print Spooler services- CVE-2021-1675 and CVE-2021-34527 which directly affect Print Spoolers installed on domain controllers, enabling remote code execution. See this link for Microsoft updates and patch information on this flaw.
In addition to this vulnerability, an existing weakness in print spoolers enabled on a DC, combined with unconstrained delegation object (see indicator 16 "Computer or user accounts with unconstrained delegation") may allow attackers to authenticate as that DC to any service (see this writeup for additional information).

ParameterXml: <Param>2021-07-08T16:25:15.1030019+00:00</Param><Param>Security principals marked with adminCount=1</Param><Param>Pass</Param><Param>100 A</Param><Param>dsp.lab</Param><Param>dsp.lab</Param><Param>Informational</Param><Param>1</Param><Param>Mitre:Privilege Escalation</Param><Param>When a security principal (user, computer, or group) has its adminCount attribute set to 1, it is considered an "Administrative" principal and its ACL will change as per the permissions on the AdminSDHolder object. This is not an exploit in and of itself, but could indicate someone is trying to use these accounts as backdoors for other activities. ParameterXml: <Param>2021-07-08T16:30:19.5146453+00:00</Param><Param>Domain controllers in an inconsistent state</Param><Param>Pass</Param><Param>100 A</Param><Param>dsp.lab</Param><Param>dsp.lab</Param><Param>Informational</Param><Param>1</Param><Param>Mitre:Resource Development, Mitre:Privilege Escalation</Param><Param>This indicator looks for domain controllers that may be in an inconsistent state, indicating a possible rogue or otherwise non-functional DC. DCs in a consistent state are characterized by the following: 1. The UserAccountControl attribute on the DC machine object has the SERVER_TRUST_ACCOUNT flag set. 2. A corresponding object of type server exists for the DC in the configuration partition. 3. Lack of domain authentication reveals out-of-sync machines. Out-of-sync domain controllers must be either reinstalled or removed. ParameterXml: <Param>2021-07-08T16:35:29.3733117+00:00</Param><Param>Well-known privileged SIDs in sIDHistory</Param><Param>Pass</Param><Param>100 A</Param><Param>dsp.lab</Param><Param>dsp.lab</Param><Param>Warning</Param><Param>1</Param><Param>Mitre:Privilege Escalation, Mitre:Defense Evasion</Param><Param>This indicator looks for security principals that contain specific SIDs of accounts from built-in privileged groups within their sIDHistory attribute. ParameterXml: <Param>2021-07-08T16:35:32.3153975+00:00</Param><Param>Users and computers with non-default Primary Group IDs</Param><Param>Pass</Param><Param>100 A</Param><Param>dsp.lab</Param><Param>dsp.lab</Param><Param>Informational</Param><Param>1</Param><Param>Mitre:Privilege Escalation</Param><Param>This indicator returns a list of users and computers whose Primary Group IDs (PGIDs) are not the defaults for domain users and computers. Users created in the domain will have a default PGID of 513 (Domain Users) or 514 (Domain Guests) while computers are 515 (Domain Computers), 516 (Domain Controllers), or 521 (RODC). The Primary Group ID is not automatically changed when a user is moved to a different group (i.e. a user moved into Domain Admins will not be assigned PGID 512). This fact can be used to hide users with privileges to systems that rely on PGID, while hiding the user from queries that rely on enumerating the member attribute without the PGID. Additionally, group objects' member attribute will not list the user objects with PGID of those groups.</Param><Param>Modifying the Primary Group ID is a stealthy way for an attacker to escalate privileges without triggering member attribute auditing for group membership changes.</Param><Param>No evidence of exposure</Param><Param>0</Param><Param>None</Param><Param>Run every hour starting on 2/3/2021 2:07:23 PM</Param>

The Primary Group ID is not automatically changed when a user is moved to a different group (i.e. a user moved into Domain Admins will not be assigned PGID 512). This fact can be used to hide users with privileges to systems that rely on PGID, while hiding the user from queries that rely on enumerating the member attribute without the PGID.
